description: "GroupTags allow you to organize and categorize multiple dots using shared tags. Instead of sorting dots one by one, you can apply a GroupTag to quickly group related content ‚Äî such as projects, tasks, teams, or topics."

## üìù How to use GroupTags

üßæ Navigate to the dot where you want to apply or view GroupTags.

üë• In the comment or annotation area, tag at least two users. (GroupTags require 2+ members to be created.)

üîó Once the users are tagged, the system will automatically group them together visually.

üìç Click on the center area of the grouped user icons. This will open a contextual option.

üÜï Choose the ‚ÄúCreate New Group‚Äù option that appears.

üè∑Ô∏è Enter the name you want for your GroupTag ‚Äî something meaningful to your project, team, or topic.

‚úÖ Click Create to finalize the group. The new GroupTag will now appear as an option in your tagging workflow.

üì£ Now, instead of tagging people individually, you can simply tag the GroupTag name, and the message will be delivered to all members in that group automatically.


::div{class="flex w-full justify-center max-w-6xl mx-auto h-120 py-4"}
:video{src="/grouptags.mp4" class="rounded-md object-cover w-full h-full" controls autoplay muted loop}
::


### üí° Tips 

* Create GroupTags for teams, squads, recurring reviewers, or topic-based collaborators.

* Keep names short and recognizable.

* GroupTags are perfect for speeding up notifications when multiple people need to see the same dot.
